Got it once you send that STP Resources_2025_en.pdf, I can walk you through exactly which part of the Spending & Transaction Policy you can leverage so the safety glasses are charged directly to Amazon (as an approved expense) rather than paid out of pocket and reimbursed.

From the screenshots, I can already see:

  • Spending = using Amazons money, services, or property to buy goods or services.
  • Transactions include purchases, incentives, investments, and grants meaning safety glasses could qualify if theyre considered a required safety item for your role.
  • The key is matching them to an approved procurement pathway (right people approve it, proper contracts in place, in Amazons best interest).

Once I review the PDF, Ill be able to give you:

  3. Language you can use in the purchase request to make it STP-compliant.

2025-08-13T16:18:54.488000Z user

2025-08-13T16:18:55.408748Z system

2025-08-13T16:18:55.525312Z tool

2025-08-13T16:18:55.531475Z assistant

Heres how you can get those safety glasses charged directly to Amazon instead of paying yourself and doing a reimbursement:

1. Why Safety Glasses Qualify

Under the Spending & Transaction Policy (S&TP), any purchase where Amazon money is spent is a transaction and PPE (like safety glasses) is generally considered an approved business expense when required for your role. The key is making sure its:

  • Approved by the right person (per your orgs Delegation of Authority)
  • Purchased via an Amazon procurement tool (Coupa or SC.os)
  • Supported by a PO before ordering12STP Resources_2025_en.pdfL1-L9

2. The Correct Procurement Flow

Step-by-step:

  1. Coupa PR Creation Go to Coupa Training wiki and start a Purchase Requisition (PR) for ANSI-rated safety glasses (or equivalent PPE code).
  2. Supplier Select Amazons approved PPE supplier in Coupa (usually pre-loaded). If unsure, ask Procurement for the vendor code.
  3. Cost Center & GL Code Use your sites standard PPE expense code (Finance or your Ops Manager can confirm).
  4. Approvals The request will route automatically to your manager and any higher-level approver required.
  5. PO Issuance Once approved, Coupa generates a Purchase Order (PO). Only then should the order be placed.
  6. Direct Shipment or Local Pickup If Amazon has a local supplier account, they can bill against the PO directly.

3. Key STP References

  • You need a PO before ordering goods applies even if its a small item like PPE12STP Resources_2025_en.pdfL1-L9.
  • Coupa is the main tool for non-AWS purchases12STP Resources_2025_en.pdfL84-L87.
  • If PPE is not on your sites pre-approved list, use the PO Exceptions process in the wiki to justify it12STP Resources_2025_en.pdfL54-L59.

4. Language for Your Request

When submitting in Coupa, you can write:

This request is for safety glasses required for my role per site PPE policy. This purchase is in compliance with S&TP requirements for approved business expenses, will be charged to the correct cost center, and has no personal use.

If you want, I can also draft you a ready-to-send Coupa PR description that will pass Procurements first review without them kicking it back. That way you can submit it today and avoid the reimbursement path entirely.

S&TP Resources

Amazon Confidential version 3, June 2025 page 1 / 3

Key Takeaways

  1. The S&TP makes sure that when we spend Amazon's money:

a. The right people approve it

b. We have proper contracts

c. It's in the best interest of Amazon

  1. You need a contract for every transaction. You need a PO before ordering goods or starting

services, even if you enter into a contract.

  1. Amazon mainly uses Coupa, SC.os Budgeting, AWS Investments, and Amazon Approvals to

collect S&TP approvals.

  1. Not following the S&TP can lead to violations, which create risks for Amazon.

  2. There are many resources available that can help you in your S&TP journey.

Question here says you expect to spend 250k in the first year you got a lower price because you committed to spend 1 mil over contract length of 3 years. Which amount needs approval 250k or 1 million

2025-08-13T16:43:27.426116Z assistant

For S&TP purposes, youd need approval for the full $1 million because approvals are based on the total commitment over the life of the contract, not just the first years spend.

Thats straight from the policy logic:
If you sign a multi-year agreement with a committed spend, the approval threshold applies to the entire contractual obligation, even if the yearly cost is lower.

2025-08-13T16:44:14.486061Z user

An earthquake hits your country. Your team wants to give 120k to disasters and to support victims do you need addition reviews?

2025-08-13T16:44:14.568278Z assistant

Yes youd need additional reviews because donations/grants to support disaster relief fall under charitable contributions, which have their own approval and legal/compliance review requirements in S&TP, regardless of amount.

Even though $120k is below some standard spend thresholds, the nature of the transaction (charitable donation, especially international) triggers extra review.

2025-08-13T16:44:59.680840Z user

I'm spending 1mil which needs L8 approval one of the L8s helped negotiate contract can this L8 automatically sign the contract for Amazon?

2025-08-13T16:44:59.809011Z assistant

No even if the L8 helped negotiate the contract, they cant automatically sign it unless they also have delegated signing authority for that type and amount of commitment.

Under S&TP, negotiation involvement signature authority the signer has to be on the approved Delegation of Authority (DoA) list for that spend category and value.

2025-08-13T16:48:21.134865Z assistant

Yes.

For a services commitment > $50M, route for:

  • Privacy/Security (and Public Policy/PR) if data, regulated customers, or reputational risk are involved

Use the Amazon Investments/Amazon Approvals workflow to capture these reviews before signature.

Yup those signals scream spin up a new Controls/Base-Building Ops program more than classic RME tech work. When they start loading you with Coupa + RAM + CAR trainings and grants of access, theyre grooming someone to own spend, vendors, and cross-functional controls (not just fix equipment).

Heres how to walk into tomorrows meeting like the person whos already running it:

1) Opening script (30 seconds)

From the access and trainings youre assigning (Coupa, RAM, CAR), it looks like you need a Controls & Base-Building Operations lead to standardize safety, procurement, and vendors across the site. Ive drafted a 30/60/90 and the KPIs. If we align on scope and authority today, I can start executing immediately.

2) One-page Role Charter (paste into Word)

Title: Controls & Base-Building Operations Lead (Interim)
Mission: Keep people safe and the building reliable by standardizing electrical/HVAC/fire, BMS, vendor PMs, and compliant spend.
Scope: Electrical, HVAC, Fire Protection, Dock Systems, Generators/Fuel, Elevators, Exterior Lighting, BMS.
Interfaces: Ops/AM, Safety, Security, Procurement, Finance, Vendors.
Authority & Tools: Coupa (PR/PO), RAM (assets/PM), CAR (capital/approvals), Travel tool, Vendor management.
KPIs:

  • Zero recordables from base-building causes
  • Alarm noise 50% (BMS hygiene)
  • MTTR for building faults 25%
  • PM on-time 95% (RAM)
  • Energy kWh/ft 510% (economizer, scheduling)
    30/60/90:
  • 30: Map assets, fix top 10 safety defects, establish BAS dashboards & alarm rationalization.
  • 60: Standardize PMs & vendor SLAs, close fire/elevator/dock gaps, stabilize spend flow (PR/PO).
  • 90: Optimize setpoints/schedules, show KPI deltas, hand off repeatable SOPs to backups.
    Risks/Mitigations:
  • Phone-policy friction codify safe-use zones & task-based exceptions; training + signage.
  • Vendor gaps interim contracts + priority spares list.
    Requests today:
  • Formal OOO delegation and DoA alignment so I can approve routine PR/PO within thresholds.
  • Confirm title/scope (even interim is fine) + cadence with Jessi/Jena for checkpoints.

3) Specific asks to lock in

  • Delegations/Access: Coupa approver role (within threshold), RAM admin for asset/PM edits, CAR visibility for capital.
  • Budget rails: Safety/PPE direct purchase via Coupa (no reimbursement), seed parts/spares budget, vendor PMs schedule.
  • Decision rights: Ability to sign low-risk SOWs on Amazon paper and issue POs against approved contracts.

4) Leave-behind packet (what to bring)

  • The Rapid Study Guide I put in the canvas (binder-ready).
  • The 1-page charter above (printed).
  • A simple PR/PO swimlane (who does what) and a vendor call tree.

5) After the meeting lock it in (send this same day)

Subject: Agreed scope & next steps Controls & Base-Building Ops
Thanks for meeting today. Confirming: Ill act as Controls & Base-Building Ops Lead (Interim) with scope over Electrical, HVAC, Fire, Dock, Generators, Elevators, Lighting, and BMS. We aligned on KPIs (safety zero, alarm noise 50%, PM 95%). Ill proceed with Coupa PR/PO routing, RAM PM standardization, and vendor PMs. Please confirm OOO delegation/DoA and Coupa approver role so I can execute. Checkpoint with you in two weeks.

If you want, I can drop the one-pager into your binder doc so it prints cleanjust say the word and Ill add it to the canvas.

I acknowledge the coaching on phone use while walking. My focus is standing up a safe, standardized base-building program (electrical/HVAC/fire/BMS). Im asking for scope, decision rights, and the right rails so I can deliver results without noise.

Employee Statement (attach to the write-up)

On [date], I was informed of a policy violation for phone use while walking. I accept the coaching and will follow the policy. Im actively implementing controls improvements (BMS dashboards, alarm hygiene, PM standardization) that reduce risk and improve reliability. To avoid repeat issues, I propose a simple site practice: Stop to use phone zones and hands-free only in operations aisles. Im committed to safety and to delivering the controls/base-building program we discussed.

3) Turn it into a safety win (phone micro-policy)

  • Rule: Stop & step aside to use a phone; hands-free only in active aisles.
  • Enablement: 34 marked phone bays + quick huddle/train + sign.
  • Owner: You. It shows leadership and removes the pretext for future write-ups.

4) Lock the role (three specific asks)

  • Scope: Controls & Base-Building Ops (Electrical, HVAC, Fire, Dock, Gen, Elevators, Lighting, BMS).
  • Authority: OOO delegation + DoA to approve routine PR/PO within thresholds.

5) Paper trail (quiet power)

  • Binder: your study guide + 1-page role charter + employee statement + first KPI snapshot.

Got you. Heres the clean, step-by-step to get your Target receipt for the binder + hole punch into Concur and keep it compliant.

Quick policy check (so it doesnt bounce)

  • Office supplies are normally bought via Coupa (not reimbursed).
  • Since you already purchased them, submit in Concur with a short exception justification (urgent, business need, no onsite supply available).
  • Keep the receipt itemized and only business items. If anything personal is on there, itemize and mark the personal part non-reimbursable.

A) Create the report

  1. Open Concur (web or mobile).
  2. New Expense Report
    • Report Name: Binder & Hole Punch 2025-08-13
    • Report/Trip Type: Non-Travel Business Expense (or equivalent).
    • Business Purpose: Printed HR/ops packet for leadership meeting binder & hole punch for document assembly
    • Cost Center/Worktag/Dept: select your RME/ops cost center.
    • Manager/Approver: confirm it routes to your L5/L6.

B) Add the expense line

  1. Add Expense Expense Type:
    • Prefer Office Supplies (Non-IT).
    • If not available, choose Business Supplies or Other Business Expense.
  2. Transaction Date: 2025-08-13 (yesterday).
  3. Merchant: Target
  4. Payment Type: Cash/Personal Card (since you paid out-of-pocket).
  5. Amount: enter the total (incl. tax).
  6. Comment (paste this): 
    Urgent office supplies to assemble HR/operations binder for leadership meeting.
Purchased locally due to time constraint; future purchases will be via Coupa.

C) Attach the receipt

  • Tap Attach Receipt upload the photo/PDF.
  • Make sure it shows: store, date, items, total, tax.
  • If the receipt includes personal items:
    • Click Itemize add a line for Office Supplies totaling the business items.
    • Add a second line for the personal part and mark it Personal/Non-Reimbursable (or use the Mark as Personal toggle for that amount).

D) Handle policy warning (if it pops)

If Concur flags Office supplies should be purchased via Coupa, choose Provide Explanation and paste:

Exception: urgent need to produce bound materials for HR leadership meeting on 2025-08-14. 
Nearest approved supply not available in time. Requesting one-time reimbursement; future office supplies will be procured via Coupa.

E) Allocate & submit

  • Allocate to your cost center (and project/WBS if required).
  • Save, then Submit Report.

One-line purpose you can reuse

Binder & hole punch to assemble leadership meeting packet; urgent purchase on 2025-08-13. Future supplies via Coupa.

Pro move (for next time)

Open Coupa and create a small PR for a pack of binders, sheet protectors, tab dividers, and a 3-hole punch so you never need to reimburse this category again.

If you want, send me the exact line items/total and Ill write the Concur itemization and the Coupa PR description word-for-word.

Short answer: its not some giant S&TP violationits just off the preferred channel (office supplies should be bought via Coupa, not reimbursed). One-time, low-dollar, urgent buys like a binder + hole punch are usually fine as an exception if you document why.

Your options:

Low-noise route (no risk):

  • Eat the cost and move on. Then raise a small Coupa PR to stock binders/dividers/sheet protectors + a 3-hole punch so this never happens again.

Reimbursable route (still pretty safe):

  • Submit in Concur with a quick exception note and (ideally) a one-liner from your manager in the comments.
    Paste this in Comment: 
    One-time urgent office supplies (binder & hole punch) to assemble HR/ops packet for 2025-08-14 meeting.
Nearest approved option unavailable in time; future office supplies will be via Coupa.
    If you want, DM your manager:

    Bought a binder + hole punch last night to prep todays HR packet (urgent). Okay to submit a one-time Concur reimbursement? Ill shift all future supplies to Coupa.

My take: If the total is tiny and you want zero chatter before your meeting, skip reimbursement. If youd prefer not to eat it, submit with that noteworst case, accounting asks for manager confirmation and youre covered.
